Award.AwardTitle: Using Early Introduction to Undergraduate Research to Recruit, Retain, and Graduate More STEM Majors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Bucknell Scholars (BUScholars) program provides financial support for approximately 95 science and mathematics majors to participate in two summers of research, starting the summer before they matriculate at Bucknell University in Pennsylvania. BUScholars participate in a summer transition research program, a new STEM-themed living/learning community, special first-year coursework (STEM foundation seminars), and a new interdisciplinary STEM discussion group, all of which help create an environment that encourages student enthusiasm and success in STEM disciplines. A specific goal of the BUScholars program is to increase the number of students from underrepresented groups achieving STEM degrees. Retention of students in STEM majors is improved through proactive mentoring and supplemental academic support. Establishing a strong peer support system through the new living/learning community, participation in high quality research opportunities, and dedicated academic and post-program advising greatly increases the likelihood of success for students while at Bucknell and later as they enter STEM careers.

The program intends to increase the number of natural science and mathematics majors at Bucknell by 30% over 5 years. An assessment of the BUScholars program, particularly the perceptions and reactions of the participants, is being combined with results from the two similar STEP projects that incorporate early introduction of summer undergraduate research at Hamilton College in New York and Armstrong Atlantic State University in Georgia. All participating STEP students are being tracked on a long-term basis, with an emphasis on final academic and career choices, and the results are being shared with the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

STEM Scholars was designed to prepare undergraduate students for long-term careers in science, either in academia or in industry, through an early introduction to research. Six strong and diverse cohorts of approximately 15 students each were recruited and participated in activities designed to help them transition to college, introduce them to research, and help to establish close working relationships with STEM faculty and peer mentors during a summer 5-week pre-matriculation experience and follow-up 10-week research experience after their first, second, or third year of college.

In the first summer, each cohort worked closely with a faculty mentor and research team as their primary activity. They were also introduced to faculty of each STEM department through a departmental hosted luncheon, exposed to the academic support resources on campus through a series of lunch experiences called the Academic Success Lunches, mentored by an upper class STEM major, and participated in weekend field trips to expose them to various STEM-related sites around central PA.  In the second year, students were funded for a 10-week summer research experience. The students were provided the freedom to choose the faculty member with which they would like to work. Many continued with their first-year summer experience while others sought out faculty who were not already part of the STEM Scholars program.

Two anticipated outcomes of this grant were to increase the overall number of STEM majors from the Natural Sciences and Mathematics at Bucknell and to achieve at least a 75% STEM retention rate among the STEM Scholars.  Compared with the baseline data presented in our original proposal, the number of Natural Science and Mathematics majors has increased by 16% as of fall 2019.  Retention data is reflected in the table below.  In our data collection, we maintained a comparison group that also attended Bucknell. They were demographically similar to our STEM Scholars.

This chart shows, for example, that from the first cohort (2014 Cohort) that 68% of the students who began as a STEM major at Bucknell, graduated as a STEM major in four years. From the STEM Scholars Cohort 2014, the 4-year graduation rate was 93%, all except one student in the original cohort graduated from Bucknell with a STEM major. We found that in the first 4 cohorts, STEM Scholars retained/graduated at a higher rate than the comparison group. We also found that STEM Scholars retained/graduated at a higher rate than the Bucknell STEM majors in each cohort except Class of 2021 as of spring 2019. Persistence in a STEM major, particularly for those who may experience stereo-type threat, appears to be related to an understanding that failure is a part of learning and a cohort of supportive colleagues plays an important role.  (Note that the 2018 and 2019 Cohorts are not included in this table since it is still too early to know if they are going to persist in STEM.)

The two key outcomes learned regarding building a successful pre-matriculation program to increase retention of STEM majors were: 1) engaging students in authentic STEM research with a faculty mentor, 2) supporting cohort building activities by recruiting, training, and working alongside peer mentors.

Broader Impacts

An additional goal of this program was to increase the number of students from underrepresented groups in Natural Science and Mathematics majors at Bucknell. The cohorts were selected based on a supplemental admissions application, particularly focused on recruiting students of color, females-except Biology/Animal Behavior/Neuroscience, students from low socio-economic backgrounds, and first generation college students. On average, each of our participants met two of these four criteria.  In addition, the overall number of racial/ethnic minority students in Natural Science and Mathematics majors increased by 6% over the baseline data in our original proposal.
